title: Before 1 March 2019, will the U.S. impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers for the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi?
preds: While there is the time aspect in my favor, there are other reasons why there is such a low probability of Trump imposing sanctions.  Although Trump has threatened punishment if word came out that Khashoggi was killed, we have learned by now that Trump frequently threatens and does not always follow up with action. He also said how it would hurt the U.S. if we stopped military sales to Saudi Arabia, which is seemingly more important to him. This situation has also died down more or less and was more of a hot topic in October of 2018.

President Trump would not risk the potential of losing a valuable source of oil. In that case, it would not be worth it for him to investigate a journalist's death. Therefore, he will not impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers.
The president has passed sanctions in the past without much pressure from the senate. In this case he is under pressure from the two parties and has no credible reason not to oblige.

Congress has had bipartisan efforts to impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions on high ranking members of Saudi Arabia's government, but the Trump Administration continues to hold off on taking any serious action.  This is even after the CIA concluded that the Crown Prince order the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.  There is no reason to think that the Trump Administration will take any action in the next two days, especially with it having to prepare for anything the Mueller report says.

In the past, Trump as not done any extraordinary measures to help a citizen overseas. Also, he cares about his relationship with his foreign ally too much to want to disrespect them with sanctions and accusal.

Saudi Arabia wants to purchase billions of dollars worth of military equipment, and Trump wants to keep them as an economic ally. His financial interests most likely outweigh the mystery of a journalist distant from home. Imposing sanctions would hurt the United States as well, so the Global Magnitsky Sanctions are not likely to be passed.

Using Mill's method of agreement, we can use former President GW Bush who did not impose any sort of sanctions on Saudi Arabia after 9/11, an objectively more tragic event than Khashoggi's killing, even though 15/19 of the hijackers were Saudis and there were many reports of their involvement. Using Mill's method of disagreement, we can use former President Obama who also did not impose any sort of sanctions regardless of their distancing relationship due to opposing ideas on the Syrian civil war and the US-sponsored Iran nuclear deal. Using these methods, it is very unlikely that Trump will impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions despite disapproving of the killing

Given the number of domestic (+ Hanoi Summit) issues occurring this last week of February, it is unlikely that President Trump will likely decide to impose further sanctions on SA extended from those already imposed on November 15th of 2018 (https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm547). The media cycle and public perception have also already shifted away from SA, with far lower attention paid to it now then at the zenith of the controversy.

According to the Washington Post, following in the October 2, 2018 death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, a group of senators from both political parties wrote a letter to United States President Donald Trump asking "g for an investigation and a determination of whether to impose sanctions on foreign government officials because of Khashoggi’s reported disappearance, 'including with respect to the highest ranking officials in the Government of Saudi Arabia'" (Tama). In this letter, the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act was used. As result there is 120 days, or 4 months, for the Trump to decide to impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers for the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. To how now been over 120 days, so as a result of this I conclude that the US will not impose Global Magnitsky Sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers for the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
Works Cited: 
Tama, Jordan. “What Is the Global Magnitsky Act, and Why Are U.S. Senators Invoking This on Saudi Arabia?” The Washington Post, WP Company, 12 Oct. 2018, www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/10/12/what-is-the-global-magnitsky-act-and-why-are-u-s-senators-invoking-this-on-saudi-arabia/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.b27209a67a74.

Comments: KSA initiates it's charm offensive. Affirming forecast.
CNN, February 24, 'Saudi Arabia appoints first female ambassador to the US': https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/24/politics/saudi-appoints-us-ambassador/index.html
Comments: Incremental adjustment for the passage of time.

Comments: WH foot-dragging. Affirming forecast.
Al-Jazeera, February 10, 'Top Republican blasts White House over Khashoggi update failure - White House had until Friday to report to Congress on the killing of the Saudi writer, but it missed the deadline': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/02/top-republican-blasts-white-house-khashoggi-update-failure-190210074345069.html
Daily Sabah, February 4, 'Erdoğan reveals some Khashoggi hit squad members may be dead': https://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2019/02/05/erdogan-reveals-some-khashoggi-hit-squad-members-may-be-dead
Clip from Sabah article:
"They [Saudi Arabia] say 22 people are under arrest but according to our information, some of them may not be alive. They may have been victims of ‘traffic accidents' because the system there is working very odd," Erdoğan said during a comprehensive interview on Turkey's public broadcaster TRT.
The president suggested that Riyadh may be trying to cover up the deaths with incidents such as traffic accidents. He said he believes this to be the case since "the kingdom is far from conducting a clear and transparent investigation in the case."

Comments: 1) The consulate is sovereign territory. Without the full cooperation of the KSA, see this effort as ineffective. 2) In the USA, WH vs Congress over government funding/border security takes precedence. 3) IFP time constraint. Affirming forecast.   
Al-Jazeera, January 28, 'What can an investigation into Khashoggi's murder achieve? - A UN-led team is in Turkey to investigate journalist's murder and wants access to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul': https://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidestory/2019/01/investigation-khashoggi-murder-achieve-190128180753515.html
Clip from article:
"But neither the journalist's body nor remains have been recovered, and the murder case remains unsolved."
Trump wont stop letting them buy weapons from us because they will just buy from another country
The U.S really doesn't wanna piss off their oil supply.

I do not think the answer is zero for two reasons: 
Pressure from the House Committee to be seen to be making a visible gesture
A possible gesture from the King to the followers of MbS that they are not 'safe' yet, as a sacrificial gesture to the world but also a warning shot to internal politico's, which could be set up using actions covertly agreed with the US. 
The decision will not be Trump's but (as we speak) intermediated by Bolton and Pompeo.  Trump is on record as saying it was a stupid thing to do, so could be presented as his strategy. Could be a way to bring KSA in from the cold a little faster, if they present it as a 'mea culpa' and don't fight accusations.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

Comments: A good instructional: Lying: Caught In a Lie - WHAT WERE YOU THINKING: https://youtu.be/HAt3j_ZDHRQ
USA Today, January 13, 'Secretary of State Pompeo to press Saudi Arabia to provide a 'credible narrative' on Jamal Khashoggi's murder': https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2019/01/13/mike-pompeo-press-saudis-credible-narrative-jamal-khashoggi/2552630002/
Clips from article:
"A senior State Department official told reporters that Pompeo would press Saudi Arabia to provide “a credible narrative for what happened in the consulate and subsequent events.” The remarks came during a Jan. 4 media briefing to preview Pompeo's trip. 
This official, who spoke on background to adhere to State Department policy, said that so far, the Saudis account has not “hit that threshold of credibility and accountability.” He said the administration wants to work with the Saudis to underscore it’s “in their interest to pursue this as aggressively as they can to get this albatross off their backs.”  
But foreign policy experts say it sounds like Pompeo's goal is to quiet the controversy rather than hold the Saudis accountable. Lawmakers in both parties have looked for ways to penalize Saudi Arabia for its role in Khashoggi's death, including curbing U.S. support for the Saudi's bombing campaign in Yemen and halting arms sales to the kingdom."
Affirming forecast.
The Saudis must be punished, but trump will will keep the punishment minimal on unimportant persons.

Update due to time elapsed since initial forecast.  News coverage has died down on the matter, putting less pressure on the administration to go after the Council of Ministers for the murder. [Sanctions on 17 individuals for Khashoggi murder](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/2018/11/15/4385a472-e8e8-11e8-a939-9469f1166f9d_story.html?utm_term=.df4ce0ccd5fe) is highly likely to be the only sanctions imposed on Saudi individuals at this point in time.
Going to just drop to zero given the close relations between the trump and saudi families. Also the money they are spending on US weapons.

It is very unlikely that President Trump will make a determination finding responsibility for MBS or any other members of the Saudi government in Khashoggi's killing. Moreover, the US Congress and the American public are distracted by many other domestic issues to pressure the administration into action. Finally, the Trump Administration is very transactional - recently the idea to use an Arab force to fight Daesh in Syria has been floated and this will likely require Saudi support. The need for Saudi support will mitigate action on the Khashoggi case.
It is difficult to imagine Don Trump will freeze the assets or deny a visa to bin Salman or other senior Saudi officials, given the mutual relations between the two governments.
I do believe Congress has the guts to do this.  Trump doesn't.
the trump administration and his family have to many ties to the kingdom.

Donald Trump will never decide to impose sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers. He will say that what the Saudi leadership has done to punish the perpetrators is sufficient. Trump will claim that the Council of Ministers was not involved and that the U.S. can't risk the "billions" of dollars of arms sales to the Saudi government.
The concerned US parties stand to make too much money from Saudi interests both before and after 01/03/2019.

Khashoggi's death has slipped out of the media's focus, there is no political will in the US to take any significant action as a direct result of his death. Even when tied to the plight of Yemenis it has created little or no action other than words and rhetoric. Trump will absolutely not act against the Saudis in a meaningful way he has made his position crystal clear on the Saudis as important to him in the region, although one has to question why that is so.
Trump Is entirely transactional and does not care about ethics or the morality of issues.
Congress will not succeed in passing legislation
WE should , but President will veto.
too much money for Trump's family will stop this

Comments: I'd be curious to see which country Pompeo visits first. No matter, this feels like back-burner stuff now; House shake-up and govt shutdown taking up much of WH attention. Affirming forecast.
Al-Jazeera, January 4, 'Pompeo to push for GCC unity, press Saudis on Khashoggi on visit': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/pompeo-push-gcc-unity-press-saudis-khashoggi-visit-190104173831280.html

this act has been in place since 2012 and already has 18 individuals listed, including 2 people involved in the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, meaning it is active and in frequent use even under the Trump administration and even for this case (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitsky_Act). It has also already been "initiated" (by this question's description)  against even the 'highest ranking' officials in Saudi Arabia, though it is unclear what this exactly defines and how Trump will go about it. The question really is then how many people are in SAs council of ministers and how much the king/prince care to protect them. (caveat: does this have to be imposed on an *acting* member of the council or does it count if its one from now but they have since been removed? because i can see this being a compromise and its not clear what the technical result for this question is here). there seem to be about 23-30 ministers and 7 ministers of state, maybe one would used as a strawman.
It is actually the responsibility of the treasury and secretary of state to decide - https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-memorandum-secretary-state-secretary-treasury/

I believe part of the Syria Withdrawal is an effort to disentangle from the Saudi/Turkish clash in Syria, which combined with our with holding of support in Yemen, pretty well leaves mbs TO HAUL HIS OWN WATER. While this does not satisfy the question, it may have greater impact on the region than the Magnitsky action.

The Leader Of The Free World regards the Saudi leadership as vital to his popularity and the murder of journalists as a public service.  The spineless Congressional members of what used to be the Republican Party are okay with this.  Pretty soon I shall have to stop being a Republican, I suppose.

Recent US actions on Yemen lead me to reduce likelihood further. What should have been a fairly easy resolution relating to food supplies and humanitarian aid to get to Hodeida was nearly scuppered by US insistence on changing the wording. This was clearly done in the interests of the Saudi-led coalition.
Down to zero. The Khashoggi murder seems to have faded from western consciousness.

1. The Senate Committee on foreign relations submitted a request on 20 November 2018 to the administration for the clarification of the crown princes role in Khashoggi's murder. I quote: "we request that your determination specifically address whether Crown Prince Mohamed bin Salman is responsible for Mr. Khashoggi’s murder". Under the magnitsky act, the administration as 120 days to respond to the request - meaning a response is due by 20 March 2019. This lies just outwith the range of the forecasting question, but of course a response can be submitted earlier. Its also worth noting that despite the oft-reported partisan divide in the US, there is actually a decent degree of consensus within Congress on the need for Saudi Arabia (or, rather, the crown prince specifically) to be punished for this. This includes the Republican controlled Senate both now and after the Democrats take over in the House. Look at the legislation (JASTA) relating to 9/11 victims and their attempt to hold Saudi Arabia responsible for the September 2001 attacks if you want to see an example of bipartisan consensus on this issue.

Comments: Doing an about-face on this one due to recent Congressional move (Khashoggi resolution tied to the more important Yemen message) and @Raahul_Kumar comments to my last post. Lower-level operatives losing their heads ensures their silence and from others involved. Assume 'cleaners' have much of their work completed. Brutal, but a reality.
CNN, December 13, 'Senate rebukes Trump, condemns Saudi crown prince for Khashoggi murder': https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/13/politics/corker-saudi-crown-prince-khashoggi/index.html
Raising this marginally owing to pressure from the recent senate vote. Still base case that it wont happen

Comments: The Khashoggi audio leaked into mainstream media? I wouldn't discount it. 
Global Risk Insights (risk assessment), December 9, 'Saudi Arabia can manage Turkey’s Khashoggi pressure campaign': https://globalriskinsights.com/2018/12/saudi-turkey-khashoggi/
Staying with my 2 percent. Admin seems strongly disinclined; if the WH decides it needs to throw a bone to the Senate, more likely to something related to the Yemen war.

I don't see Pompeo showing any opposition to Trump's negation of sanctions going higher than they already have, and his practical outlook is likely to drive him toward supporting core Saudi players for political and economic reasons.  Mnunchin obviously hasn't and is very unlikely to do anything.  And if this is all up to the Secretary of State, Attorney General and Treasury Secretary to make final decisions on, then this seems extremely unlikely even if evidence comes out showing MBS on video or audio checking in with his people in the embassy while the deed is in progress.  The Senate can rage all they want since power to make this decision doesn't ultimately seem to be in their camp and since the law is so new that there is little precedent to hold anyone accountable to sufficient "credible evidence" of wrongdoing.
Despite 2$ a gal prices at the pump, I expect a staged backlash and sanctions after the next congress is sworn in.

The Leader Of The Free World, who often announces that he is very intelligent, does not believe anything he doesn't believe, evidence to the contrary notwithstanding.  Apparently he is of the school of not-quite-thought which holds that what is true depends on who believes it and how smart they say they are.  He will not let this happen to one of his BFFs, and his minions in the Congress are sufficiently in his thrall to go along.

"Trump has repeatedly avoided rebuking Saudi Arabia, pointing to the economic benefits of U.S. arms sales to Saudi Arabia and Riyadh’s role in preventing a spike in oil prices. He’s also argued its unknowable whether the crown prince was involved."
https://www.defensenews.com/congress/2018/12/05/mattis-and-pompeo-misleading-in-khashoggi-briefing-senator-says/

Political pressure will build, from both sides of the aisle, to do so.  Trump will have no choice; it's the most he can do and keep the relationship with the Saudis on track, which is essential as a bulwark against Iran.
There is no chance of any sanctions if any kind. Trump loves a bromance with political despots and he is unlikely to lose his love for the Saudis anytime soon

Though Senators have increased their public pressure on President Trump to sanction members of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers, it is highly unlikely that this will occur. The United States relies heavily on arms sales with Saudi Arabia that the President has frequently expressed his support for. Additionally, the Intelligence Community has produced a solid presentation of evidence that links the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia directly to Khashoggi's murder, and President Trump continued to voice his support for the royal family. While Congress will likely continue to pressure the President, it is unlikely that he will impose any sanctions that would halt the sale of U.S. arms and complicate oil sales.

I believe there is a 30% chance the US will impose sanctions on upon a member of the Saudi Council of Ministers. The murder of Jamal Khashoggi had profound effects in the West and angered many Americans. There was a request from the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee for President Trump to further investigate the murder, and the CIA has confirmed that the Crown Prince ordered the murder (NYT and CFR). However, President Trump has continued to express his heavy support for the Crown Prince and his family (WashPo). He has even gone so far as to doubt the CIA's results. It is for these reasons I don't not believe the White​ House will establish sanctions against the Saudis.

Trump has refused to even condemn the actions of the Saudi Crown prince so invoking the Magnitsky would be a very unexpected turn of events. He has maintained the importance of our relationship with SA and called MBS a "great ally." He has even had discussions around repealing the act showing his disdain for it. He has spoken critically of the US pushing a human rights agenda, and we have historically remained soft when it comes SA.

Probably not. Some officials will be sanctioned, but it's unlikely that any high level person will be included. Trump at the very least he wants to retain the Saudi alliance against Iran, and is probably skittish about who might replace the hawkish MbS. Trump won't sanction any minister unless MbS effectively gives the OK.

That's the law. Democrats will hold open hearings showing the Crown Prince's complicity and the Trump family's  financial entanglements with the Saudis. Even the Republicans  won't be able to stomach firestorm

Getting involved in this was a bad idea, but thats behind us. If we confirm our values in sanctions against a nation with-out due process, we open our selves up to the same. What if Hungarian officials, having closely followed the arc of HRC'S career, and she had been elected, they could come forth with allegations that HRC has been involved in too many rumored deaths to be allowed to hold office? THats where ignoring national sovereignty comes in, and why its good policy.

US’s best friend Saudi Arabia is in trouble – against open murder of a journalists even the “almighty” US is might less. Now the empire will be shaken even more – The Petrodollar scheme is disintegrating further … . Trump can't sanction any one meaningfully except the prince him self, but if he does it, it will mean the end of US empire IMMEDIATELLY. 
However, because he can't do it - except for some Saudi ministers to safe the face - it will spill the end of the last peaces of moral "integrity"  the US supposedly had - it really never possessed it, though. I think about genocide on Native Americans, Holocaust, Hiroshima, Drop-shot plans, etc. .... Google them ..
I predict by 2025 US will become to a very strong country, but will loose it’s empire – for the good of all humanity, the population of US included. Mr.Reason.

Comments: Trump minimizes CIA declaration and overtly backs MBS. There appears to be bi-partisan support in Congress for sanctions on higher-ranking members of the Saudi government despite 'red-line' statement from the FM: Al-Jazeera, November 21, 'Saudi FM: Calls for leadership change a 'red line'
Adel al-Jubeir takes to airwaves to defend Prince Mohammed and terms Khashoggi's killing as 'unfortunate accident': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/11/saudi-fm-blasts-outrageous-report-prince-won-king-181122013903791.html
Tipping point: Expect more intelligence on Khashoggi to surface soon. Looking for demand from HPSCI and SSCI for related NSA SIGINT, CIA DA and ODNI data captures and assessments. Raw intelligence may prove highly influential in decision-making. 
USA Today, November 22, 'Report claims CIA has ‘smoking gun phone call’ linking Saudi crown prince to Jamal Khashoggi killing; Trump still stands by Saudis': https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2018/11/22/cia-saudi-crown-prince-jamal-khashoggi-killing-report/2085273002/
Clip from Today article:
"According to Hürriyet Daily News, Haspel "signaled" during her trip to Ankara the existence of a wiretapped phone call between the crown prince and his brother Khaled bin Salman that captured the order. Khaled bin Salman is Saudi Arabia’s U.S. ambassador. Hürriyet Daily News did not identify the source of its claim."
Trump appears to have received the CIA's opinion on MBS' involvement and has either disagreed or determined that the US-Saudi relationship is too important to jeopardize with further sanctions.
The Magnitsky Sanctions have not been imposed on any member of Saudi Arabia's council of Ministers. That list of people includes the King and the Crown Prince himself.

US introduced sanctions against 17 Saudis, including Saud Al-Qahtani, but not any member of the Council of Ministers. This suggests the US has determined who they are holding responsible for Kashoggi's murder. Still not impossible that further individual sanctions are added, but it seems unlikely at this point, barring further revelations.
It would be surprising if this goes all the way to the top within the 120 day timeframe.
Blame seems to be focused on Saud al-Qahtani, who is not a member of the Council of Ministers.

It's unlikely that Trump will give up on the "relationship" he has formed with the Saudis, especially due to his seeming lack of serious concern for human rights abuses. The worst of the domestic outrage has passed, with the news cycle now dominated by the US midterms. In addition, the international outrage has crested with the release of tapes to western governments by Turkish President Erdogan, from here on out there will probably be symbolic gestures against the Saudi government with any possible decision held out past Jan 1 and late into the required period of 120 days in order to minimize the public outcry.
The administration will make a couple of mostly symbolic gestures, but nothing "real," like Magnitsky.

he Trump administration is ending air refueling flights for the Saudi military campaign in Yemen and preparing sanctions against Saudis linked to the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, current and former American officials said on Friday. The moves would impose a limited punishment on the kingdom. The steps appear calibrated to respond to international outrage over the death of Mr. Khashoggi and to thousands of civilian deaths in the Yemen war, but avoid directly punishing the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, and could head off tougher congressional action.

Within the next few months, although there is uproar about the US taking actions against Saudi Arabia, there is a slight chance that President Trump will impose sanctions. The kingdom forms the foundation of President Donald Trump's Middle East policy, and a decision to severely punish its rulers could spark an estrangement that would cripple his hopes of confronting Iran. It would also weaken Washington's strategic position in the region and offer an opening to rival powers (CNN). For President Trump, his reluctance thus far has shown his desire to not break any ties with Saudi Arabia. Pressure is also on congress to psuh for these sanctions, but there is no way in telling if they are willing to push the president in this direction. Talk about sanctioning Saudi Arabia is focused on the Global Magnitsky Act, legislation that authorizes sanctions targeting individuals responsible for gross human rights abuses. That is because the Trump administration has shown little desire to hold autocrats to account, while Congress has a role in Magnitsky sanctions. Congress cannot force the executive to impose sanctions but can embarrass it for choosing not to (POLITICO). It will be interesting to see how things go after these midterms and to see if the givernment will pursue such sanctions, yet the chances are still low.
These actions must be taken to placate domestic and international political pressures.

one cannot kill a journalist and expect to walk. The journalists are always a target when reporting a story so what story was the man trying to tell when he was killed. The sanctions should be against the parties responsible for the death of a journalist and have deterrent power.

This is very unlikely.  This is at the discretion of POTUS, this particular law is potentially reminding of the Russia problem, other than Russia, this law seems usually to target smaller persons in smaller countries.  Saudi Arabia is a monarchy, and a vital partner in the ME, almost an ally. This is just so very very unlikely.

I believe there is a 0% chance that the US will impose the Global Magnitsky Sanctions on any member of Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers for the death of Jamal Khashoggi. My basis for this claim is that if the US were to apply the sanction, "The moment that a person is added to a Magnitsky List in the West, it destroys their way of life. Every financial institution will close their account, and they will be denied entry to every desirable area in the world." By using the sanctions, all the work Trump put in to create such close transactional ties with Saudi leadership will be gone, and future ties between the US and Saudi Arabia will also suffer greatly as the royal family will not side with President Trump.
Imposing any action beyond a statement will likely result in decreased cooperation and loss of intelligence from Saudi Arabia.
Seems super unlikely trump is going to start caring about human rights more than Saudi money.

---Outside ----
Because the letter was co-signed [...] triggered a provision, which until now had never been used, contained in the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act of 2016
To many economic reasons, human rights don't make profit.

There is no question that once the elections are counted in the US this will be an issue with noise an this issue but there are enough Democrats that support the KSA that nothing will be done, noise yes, actions 0! Sounds familiar, coming from Congress !!!!

Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi has not been seen since he entered a Saudi Arabian consulate in Turkey on Oct. 2, prompting widespread rumors that the Saudi government is behind his disappearance. A bipartisan group of 11 Democratic and 11 Republican senators sent a letter to President Trump this week, calling for an investigation and a determination of whether to impose sanctions on foreign government officials because of Khashoggi’s reported disappearance, “including with respect to the highest ranking officials in the Government of Saudi Arabia.”

POTUS will oppose. Saudis will displays some gestures of repentance. Most Americans don't care, and the story is already fading from the headlines (Niall Ferguson called the US a superpower with attention deficit disorder). Might get some cutback in arms sales and logistic support to the Yemen war.
If there are any sanctions it will not be much. The guy is just not important enough
With 'a million' (or is it 'over a million' now?) jobs* on the line, it's highly doubtful.

Trump would leverage this in SA-US relationship for economic reasons. US is already deeply economically tied to SA. But doesn't need to freeze assets etc.
Unfortunately Jamal Khashoggi wasn't a US citizen
There is probably no direct proof that MBS was involved
MBS will crack down on his inner circle and maintain his own innocence.

It seems like the trail of blame almost certainly leads to Muhammad bin Salman and his allies, but as long as they hold power I can't imagine Trump imposing sanctions on them. There is a chance that MBS will be ousted from the position of heir apparent (and I think Turkey is trying to make that happen), but in that case I expect he will receive the same treatment as bin Nayef and be stripped of his official positions, meaning he would no longer be a member of the council of ministers.
Not a chance given Trump's appreciation for the Saudi's and their money.  He is all in on the Saudi's.

Just want to make sure I understand this Q:  The Leader Of The Free World (a) is financially beholden to Saudi Arabia but will not say for how much, (b) believes incorrectly that the US needs the Saudis for their oil and also for the struggle against Iran, and (c) thinks that arms sales are the way to peace and prosperity.  We are trying to guess out whether in these circumstances he find a need to impose sanctions merely for murdering a non-white US resident who was also a journalist.
I think I'm being optimistic at 1%. The rate at which the news cycle moves and the various administration crises occur, it's likely this will be a distant political memory by the deadline.
